ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I'm very glad this class exists. Utilities are a vital part of the energy system and understanding how they work and think is super important. The presentation of the content isn't super dynamic since Larry mostly reads slides, but he tosses in fascinating tidbits from his work experience, which is always very interesting.

The class was OK for what it was (trying to teach a dry subject). However, the assignments were not well developed, and did not provide much in the way of a challenge. In addition, in class assignments/exercises would be very very welcome, and might help with a 3 hour lecture. Grading was unclear and inconsistent (e.g. when comparing with other students, some got points and some didn't for the same answer). There is no clearly defined metric for understanding of the material, so an exam might be a better option as well.
Extremely useful material but delivered in a very boring way. The lectures needs to be livened up with student presentations, more material from outside the US, more case studies, etc.
Problem sets were incredibly helpful to my learning. Class lectures were a bit dry.
Although the course was not the most riveting, it did provide a strong basis for understanding the industry, which I really appreciated.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The depth of the material was excellent and we learnt just about everything we could on utilities and the energy industry in general in one semester! Its a lot to cover but all very necessary....
This class provided a wealth of information in a very specific subject area. The assignments were well thought-out and provided great insight to the lectures.
It was nice to have a practitioner teaching a course on electric utilities, with real experience in the field.
Provided technical understanding of utility industry, the nuances of which are essential to our transition to clean energy but are less often discussed than simple installation of renewables
The final couple projects allow you to go in-depth into a utility and a utility project, which allowed us to really dive into the issues in detail.
The professor is earnest and better than many tenured professors at FES.

The weekly homework assignments did deepen my learning. The field trip was cool but the presentation went on for a bit longer than it needed to and had a lot of overlap with basic concepts from class. That being said it's really nice ISO NE host us.
The material was very useful and structured well.
The extensive discussion on utilities matters as it relates to the energy sector
It's good to have an overall view of the electricity market in the United States.
The group project and the problem sets
The best aspects were the breadth of information covered, and the subject matter which was extensive.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Would be useful if: 1. The teams for the group project are released/setup at the beginning of class, that way students can do the group project at their own pace! 2. Assignments like the final case study/group project were tricky because finding information was hard. The sooner these assignments are released the better, gives students enough time to start taking a look and finding info. 3. Definitely more interaction but in a concrete way so for example, maybe the last 30 mins of class students can present something on the topic being discussed. Have questions for students to read up on before each and every class and have a discussion about those questions. Above all avoid the professor talking the whole time, by having students have to read up and have to discuss and maybe linking to their participation grade it will incentivize them to participate and be even more engaged. 4. It takes time, money etc to do this but maybe two field trips per semester. For example to visit a power plant or a utility. If the utility agreed you could ask a group of students to do the heavy lifting and make the logistics happen 5. Lastly the course could borrow aspects from RE Project finance to make it a practicum. Ie exercises like the deconstructing rate cases, working out tariffs etc. Maybe we could even have in class exercises so that students also leave with hard skills.
The pace of the course could use a few adjustments. Especially in the second half of the course.

Larry's a great guy, but his teaching leaves something to be desired. His slides are verbose and dry, and the content seems to be getting outdated. If I could give him two pieces of advice, they would be: 1. Make the course more engaging, in whatever way you can. I think a simple way of doing this would be to constantly be asking the class questions, instead of just lecturing to the class. The size is right to do that. If it means you can't cover as much material, that's ok. It would help people understand things better and learn more from each other. 2. Part of the name of the course is "an industry in transition" -- the content should reflect this. There is so much that's constantly changing about the electric utility industry, yet much of our reading, the slides, and graphs and data we were looking at were from 2013-2014. It would be great if the class were constantly updated to reflect the newest regulatory filings, utility proceedings, and best practices so students looking to go into the industry can get the most possible value out of the course.
In-class engagement, assignments, grading, structure, pace.

I think this class needs to be restructured and revised to truly reflect the changing nature of electric utilities and properly prepare students to enter the field. The material needs to be presented in a more engaging manner with more class dialogue. The bits of discussion were very forced and basic so it didn't really provoke much participation. The group project needs to be much more specific and engaging - it was clearly an assignment to check a box for the class and I can't say I learned much from it. I think electric utilities are really interesting and complex, but this class needs to be redone. Maybe bring in speakers who are working on the ground, and from a real range, not just from the old school industry. The last bit of the class focus on the current controversial topic and I just don't think Larry has as much experience in this sector so I still feel like I lack a lot of knowledge on these issues and this would be good opportunities for guest speakers.
The course could be a bit more interactive, especially for such a long class period.

The instructor is very slow - the lectures are very long and drawn out and not super interesting. Part of it has to do with the nature of the material - but part of it has to do with how the course is taught. It could be a lot more interactive.
Lectures were dry and information was outdated
Lectures need to be more interesting.
The course would benefit from pulling in more examples and perhaps finding ways to be more engaging for students.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: class could benefit from being more interactive. lectures were sometimes dry
There were no discussion sections.
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Perfectly, Gives a more rounded understanding of various concepts but importantly of utilities and the energy industry as a whole....

This course is integral to my program. Although this subject area is loosely covered in other courses, it was immensely helpful to me to have a course devoted exclusively to my anticipated industry taught by a seasoned professional.
It is a useful survey course on electric utilities.

Most of my other coursework has centered around the politics of transitioning to low carbon economy. This course illuminated many of the more technical challenges that we will have to address once political consensus has been built.
For the energy nerds, we need as many energy classes as we can get; this is one we all should take.
This course fits very well into my energy studies.
This is a useful course for anyone who wants to work in energy in the United States (but only pertinent to the US, nowhere else).

Course was excellent for getting a basic understanding of US electric utilities. I like that many of us had no prior exposure yet Larry didn't dumb the information down for us. Came highly recommended from previous students who wanted a US electric utilities primer, and I have been highly recommending it to students who want the same.
This course was central to what I want to learn in grad school - namely, how utilities and the energy industry operate.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: For above reasons
To better understand how electric utilities, and the market and regulatory environments in which they operate.
One of the few courses relating to energy.
To learn more about electric utilities - a complex topic - and specifically how they are being forced to change.
I am studying energy and understanding utilities is integral to addressing these types of issues.
To gain a better idea of the utilities and electricity related industries in the United States
I wanted to see if I might be interested in working for an electric utility in the future. This course helped clarify my career path a lot.
Because it is relevant to my interests in energy
I have a strong interest in the energy industry and understanding how it is designed to work.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely, learnt even more than i bargained for!
Yes.
Not as much as I would have hoped
Yes
No.

Definitely didn't get as much out of it as I wanted to and it's a bit of a wasted opportunity. Resources need to be spent on making this a better class and catered to what students want and are asking for year after year.
Yes, however I do wish that there was at least one exam to solidify my understanding of the material.
Yes
Yes and no. Yes because the course covered relevant material but no because the lectures were often long and slightly boring so I wasn't engaged throughout.
Yes. Better than expected.
The topics were interesting but it was hard to digest information in the lecture format
Mostly yes, although the depth of information covered was at times overly simplistic.
Absolutely

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Split what would otherwise have been to heavy a load evenly. Our group worked well together and pretty efficiently. There was no real downside. A project of that nature would be too much for one person, it's a great idea to have groups and perhaps the final case study could also be done in groups? Downside is teams were formed late. Teams should be decided right after shopping period so that everyone gets a full semester to work on their individual portions, it can only raise the overall quality.
With well paced deliverables, the group work in this course was fine, minimal.
Working in groups was useful, as it eased the burden individually and brought people with different strengths to be able to execute different parts of the group projects.
good structure was in place to easily split up work
One of the other members of my work group was able to do analysis that I would not have been able to do. That said, the other two members did very little work and frequently completed task very late
I would have preferred an exam to a group project. Our group project was very hypothetical and not incredibly useful to my understanding.

Larry tried too hard to split up the joint degrees and enforce a certain size of group, so the group work was less useful than it should have been. Recommend either random group assignments in the future, or letting students form whatever size and mix of group they want.
The group work was very interesting. Brought together people of different backgrounds and skills to address a problem. I also enjoyed the presentation part.

I really enjoyed the group work. The advantages are that we were able to learn from each other and split up the responsibilities of the assignment. The drawbacks were only that we didn't get much time to do the project I thought.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: There is a lot of information so be prepared to read a lot and be engaged!! It's useful information but dont expect the course to be exciting, the nature of some topics makes them less exciting but all are very useful. If you are engaged you will have a great time and learn a lot.
If you're interested in utilities, take this class. But take an afternoon nap beforehand. The evening time slot is tough.
Take this course if you are trying to shore up your knowledge on electric utilities, but know that it may not be the most engaging course in the world.
If you're in energy... you probably should as there are few other options. If you are not, you should probably avoid it and take a class that's not at FES.
Be ready for very long lectures once a week - it's hard to pay attention the whole time. That being said, the material is very useful.
Do it!
It's useful if you have no exposure to the utility industry.

I think if you're interested in the subject matter as an overview this was a terrific place to get that information. It isn't however the best place to really learn detailed information on how the specific processes work.
Very good course. I recommend taking it.
